title: Sex chromosome-autosome translocations in the leaf-nosed bats, family Phyllostomidae II. Meiotic analyses of the subfamilies Stenodermatinae and Phyllostominae
abstract: Analyses of meiotic pairing and synaptonemal complexes of the composite sex chromosomes of male phyllostomid bats with X-autosome or X-and Y-autosome translocations were performed using Giemsa and silver staining procedures. Typical mammalian sex vesicles were absent in all species analyzed. Stenodermatine species with X-autosome translocations possessed an open ring and tail configuration of the XY,Y2 trivalent. Species with both X-and Y-autosome translocations possessed a closed ring and tail configuration of the neo-XY bivalent. In both cases, the tail represented the autosomal short arm of the X paired with its homologue, either the Y2 in XY,Y2 species or the autosomal arm of the composite Y in neo-XY species. Autosomal pairing of the composite sex bivalent in neo-XY species replaced an association between the original X and Y in late prophase 1. The absence of a sex vesicle, the unusual pairing configurations of the composite sex chromosomes, and the presumed absence of meiotic nondisjunction in these species is discussed in light of current hypotheses of sex chromosome behavior in male gametogenesis in mammals. The unique behavior of the sex chromosomes in male gametogenesis in mammals has been document ed by numerous authors. Inactivation of the X chro mosome and sex vesicle formation have been proposed to be important processes in sper matogenesis (Lilschytz and Lindsley, 1972). Cytological studies of the sex vesicle indicate that it is com posed primarily of condensed chromatin (Solari, 1964, 1974; Ford and Wollam, 1966; Moses, 1977). X-inactivation manifested as cessation of mRNA synthesis has also been documented in the condensed XY bi

abstract.text: Analyses of meiotic pairing and synaptonemal complexes of the composite sex chromosomes of male phyllostomid bats with X-autosome or X-and Y-autosome translocations were performed using Giemsa and silver staining procedures. Typical mammalian sex vesicles were absent in all species analyzed. Stenodermatine species with X-autosome translocations possessed an open ring and tail configuration of the XY,Y2 trivalent. Species with both X-and Y-autosome translocations possessed a closed ring and tail configuration of the neo-XY bivalent. In both cases, the tail represented the autosomal short arm of the X paired with its homologue, either the Y2 in XY,Y2 species or the autosomal arm of the composite Y in neo-XY species. Autosomal pairing of the composite sex bivalent in neo-XY species replaced an association between the original X and Y in late prophase 1. The absence of a sex vesicle, the unusual pairing configurations of the composite sex chromosomes, and the presumed absence of meiotic nondisjunction in these species is discussed in light of current hypotheses of sex chromosome behavior in male gametogenesis in mammals. The unique behavior of the sex chromosomes in male gametogenesis in mammals has been document ed by numerous authors. Inactivation of the X chro mosome and sex vesicle formation have been proposed to be important processes in sper matogenesis (Lilschytz and Lindsley, 1972). Cytological studies of the sex vesicle indicate that it is com posed primarily of condensed chromatin (Solari, 1964, 1974; Ford and Wollam, 1966; Moses, 1977). X-inactivation manifested as cessation of mRNA synthesis has also been documented in the condensed XY bi

body_text.text: X and Y in which crossing-over and chiasma forma tion take place (Koller and Darlington. 1934; Solari, 1974) . In this case, the commonly seen end-to-end association of the XY pair in diplonema and diakinesis is interpreted as "precocious terminalization of a near terminal chiasma" (Ohno et al., 1959; Fredga and Santcsson, 1963; Solari and Tres, 1970) . The alter nate mechanism of XY pair association proposed is one in which the X and Y associate end-to-end in a non-specific way (Ashley, 1984) . Presumably, the X and Y synapse nonhomologously and the duration of pairing between the X and Y in pachynema is too short for crossing-over and chiasma formation. In stead, an achiasmatic association ensures the proper disjunction of the X and Y.

Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the unique behavior of the sex chromosomes in male gametogenesis. Lindsley (1972, 1974) hypothesized that inactivation of X-linked genes is critical for activation of Y-linked genes. Any inter ference with X-inactivation will lead to spermatogenic arrest. Ohno (1970) proposed that heteropycnosis of the X and Y function to minimize crossing-over be tween the heteromorphic sex chromosomes. Ohno (1970) also suggested that formation of the sex vesicle in pachynema may serve as a special device to insure pairing or association between the X and Y. Hayman and Sharp (1981) reported the absence of a sex vesicle in the hare wallaby Lagorchestes conspicillatus, a mar supial with multiple sex chromosome-aulosome translocations. These authors suggest that 1) the sex vesicle is suppressed as a result of the translocations and. 2) if the function of the sex vesicle is related to pairing or association of the sex chromosomes as a preliminary requirement for disjunction at anaphase 1, then this role has been replaced by pairing between homologous translocated autosomes.

The widespread occurrence of sex chromosomcautosome translocations in the leaf-nosed bats, family Phyllostomidac Tucker. 1986 ) offers an opportunity to study the meiotic behavior of com posite sex chromosomes in order to test the above hypotheses of XY pair formation and sex vesicle func tion. This report presents data from a meiotic analysis of phyllostomid species with X-autosome transloca tions (XY,Y2 types). X and Y autosome transloca tions (neo-XY types), and species with presumed XX/ XY sex chromosome systems.

Bat species analyzed in this study were collected using mist nets from natural populations in Costa Rica, Honduras. Peru, and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago and given AK or TK numbers. Specimens are preserved and deposited in the Texas Cooperative Wildlife Collection. Texas A&M University, in The Museum. Texas Tech University, or in the Carnegie Museum of Natural History. Specific localities for individual specimens arc compiled in the Appendix.

Testicular biopsies were taken from freshly killed bats either in the field or in the laboratory. The tunica albuginea was removed and the seminiferous tubules were minced either in a 0.075 M KC1 hypotonic solution or a 0.7% sodium citrate hypotonic solution. Cells suspended in 15 ml of the KCI solution were incubated at 35 C for 20 min. Cells were fixed and slides prepared following the procedure of Baker et al" (1982) . Air dried slides were stained in 4% Giemsa-phosphate buffer for 10 min. Cells suspended in 15 ml of 0.7% sodium citrate were incubated at 35 C for 40 min. The cell suspension was centrifuged gently, the supernatant decanted, and the cells were resuspended in a 4% paraformaldehyde plus 0.03% sodium dodecylsulfatc solution for 5 min. The cell suspension was centrifuged a second time, the supernatant decanted, and the cells resuspended in 4% paraformaldehyde for 5 min. 10-20 drops of the cellular suspension were dropped onto dry slides and these were air-dried. Slides were stained with silver-nitrate using the technique described by Gold and Ellison (1983) except that exposure to silver nitrate was for at least 10 min and the slides were not counterstained with Giemsa.

Bright field microscopy was conducted using a Lcitz Orthoplan microscope. A wild MPS 45/51 automatic camera system was used for photography and black and while photographs were taken using Kodalith Orthofilm 6556. type 3.

Giemsa-stained preparations were analyzed to assess the prescnce/absencc of the sex vesicle in early prophase I of meiosis and to analyze the behavior of the sex chromosomes in diplonema and diakinesis of prophase I. Silver-stained preparations were analyzed to assess the pairing formation of sex trivalents in X Y ,Y 2 species and sex bivalents in neo-XY or presumed classical XY species. 34 G G = Giemsa stain, Ag = silver stain, " = species with known X-autosome translocations (X Y ,Y 2 types), b = species with both X-aulosome and Y-autosome translocation (neo-XY types).
Meiotic analyses were performed on 78 males rep resenting 29 species in the subfamilies Stenodermatinae and Phyllostominae (Table I) .

Subfamily Slenodermatinae. In Giemsa-staincd pachynema of Artibeus species with X-autosome translocations (2n = 31J), the typical mammalian sex vesicle is absent (Fig. I) . The XY,Y2 trivalent is in an open ring and tail configuration. The tail region of the X is characteristically straight. The re mainder of the X is in a looped configuration. The tail portion of the X chromosome stains less intensely than the remainder of the X and Y and is comparable in staining intensity to the autosomal bivalents. Presumably, the tail represents the translocated auto somal segment of the X (which comprises the X short arm) paired with its homologue, the Y2. The remain der of the X and Y, are more intensely stained. The looped end of the X pairs or associates with the Y, or real Y.

Silver-stained pachytene spreads of Artibeus species with X-autosome translocations show a similar open ring and tail configuration (Fig. 2) . In general, the chromosomal axes of the XY, Y2 trivalent appear like the autosomes. No obvious thickenings or bulges of the X axis are apparent.

In late prophase I meiotic spreads (diplonema and diakinesis) of Artibeus species with X-autosome trans locations, a chiasma is formed between the autosomal X short arm and the Y2 (Fig. 3) . The distal tip of the X long arm is associated with the Y, but no chiasma is visible.

In Giemsa-stained pachytene preparations of stenodermatine species with both X-and Y-autosome translocations a sex vesicle is also absent and the composite sex bivalent is in a closed ring and tail configuration ( Fig. 4a-d ). The tail region presumably represents the paired homologous autosomal regions of the X and Y. The remainder of the X forms a loop and pairs or associates with the free end of the Y chromosome. Silver-stained pachytene spreads of stenodermatine species with both X-autosome and Y-autosome translocations show a similar closed ring and tail configuration of the XY pair (Fig. 2b) . No obvious thickenings or bulges of the sex chromosomal axes are seen.

In Giemsa-stained late prophase I preparations, a single chiasma is formed presumably between the paired autosomal tail region of the sex bivalent (e) Sturnira liliunt (AK7I67), (0 Uroderma bilobatum (AK7073), and (g) Artibeus watsoni (AK7097). Note that in (g) both ends of the X and Y arc associated whereas in (e) and (0 only one end. presumably the autosomal por tion, of the X and Y remain associated. Hor izontal bar = 10 pm. (Fig. 4e-g ). With one exception, the other ends of the X and Y are not associated in diplonema and diakinesis. In Arlibeus watsoni both ends of the X and Y remain associated through late prophase I (Fig. 4g) .

Subfamily Phyllostominae. In Giemsa-stained preparations of bats in the genera Micronycteris and Tonalia, considerable variation in sex vesicle forma tion is observed (Fig. 5) . The degree of heteropycnosis of the XY pair varied from cell to cell within each individual examined. However, in all individuals ex amined the X chromosome appears to loop around or fold back on itself. This same configuration is seen in silver-stained preparations (Fig. 6) . The X and Y chromosomal axes appear like the autosomes. No bulges or thickenings of the axes were seen. The X pairs or associates with the Y at one end and either loops around or folds back on itself so that the free end of the X is proximal to the free end of the Y.

Interpretation of meiotic configurations is facil itated by the replication banding analyses of mitotic chromosomes of the same species (Tucker, 1986) . In Artibeus species with X-autosome translocations, the Fig. 6 . Silver-stained pachytene spreads of phyllostominc species including (a, b) Tonatia bidens (AK8207) and (c) Micronyeteris megalotis (AK8I87). The XY bivalents are identified. In T. bidens the X appears to loop (a) or foldback on itself (b) so that the free end of the X approximates the free end of the Y. A looped configuration of the X is also present in (c). Horizontal bars = 10 pm. short autosomal arm of the X pairs with its homologue which is a free autosome (the Y2). The distal tip of the long arm of the X pairs or associates with the Y, or real Y. The formation of a complete synaptonemal complex between the X and Y , cannot be assessed using our techniques at the light microscopic level. Chiasma formation between the X and Y , is not seen in diplonema or diakinesis. However, replication banding of the stenodermatine X and Y , reveals the presence of a minute early-replicating region on the distal tip of the long arm and the distal tip of the Y. Their presence lends support to the hypothesis that an XY "pairing" region, which is not subject to X inac tivation, exists in mammals (Burgoyne, 1982; Polani, 1982) .

True synaptonemal complex formation between the autosomal short arm of the X and the Y2 can be inferred by the presence of a chiasma between the short arm of the X and the Y2. Chiasma formation between autosomal segments of other composite sex chromosomes has been reported in Lagorchestes conspicillatus (Hayman and Sharp, 1981) and in Gerbilluspyramidum and G. gerbillus (Wahrman et al., 1983) .

In stenodermatine species with both X-and Yautosome translocations a chiasma is formed between the autosomal segments of the X and Y, thus indicat ing synaptonemal complex formation in pachynema. With one exception, this is the only association be tween the XY bivalent that is maintained through late prophase I. It appears that pairing or end-to-end asso ciation between the original X and Y components of the sex chromosomes (both mechanisms which might function to ensure a balanced segregation of the XY pair) has been replaced by pairing and chiasma forma tion between the autosomal segments of the X and Y. An association between the original X and Y through diakinesis in A. watsoni may reflect the relative recency of the translocation of an autosome to the Y chro mosome in this genus as compared to other neo-XY stenodermatine genera .

Subfamily Phyllostominae. Replication-banded mitotic metaphases are not available for interpreta tion of the XY bivalents in the phyllostomine species examined. The X chromosome pairs or associates with the Y at one end. The looped configuration of the X is similar to that seen in stenodermatine species and may reflect an attraction between the free ends of the X and Y. This phenomenon is not unique to these bats and may represent a general tendency of unpaired ends of a bivalent to associate non-homologously (Ashley, 1983) .

In silver-stained preparations the sex chromosomal axes of both stenodermatine and phyllostomine spe cies are atypical for mammals. Little or no thickenings of unpaired regions of the X and Y axes are seen. Rather, the X and Y appear more like autosomal synaptonemal complexes. Tres (1977) suggested that thickenings of the sex chromosomal axes may result from chromatin condensation. Thus, the absence of thickenings of the sex chromosomes can be correlated with reduced chromatin condensation or lack of sex vesicle formation in these species. However, the ab sence of thickenings of the sex chromosomal axes in Psammomys obesus (Ashley and Moses, 1980) suggests another interpretation. Variation in XY behavior, as seen in silver-stained preparations, may reflect an as yet undetermined species-specific phenomenon.

Sex vesicle formation and function. The absence of a sex vesicle in phyllostomid bats can be correlated with the replication patterns of the X chromosome in female somatic cells (Tucker, 1986) . Late replication of the X is reported to occur in premeiotic spermatogonial cells (Odartchenko and Pavillard, 1970) and occurs at a similar developmental stage to that of reactivation of the allocyclic X in female germ cells (Gartler et al., 1980) . Presumably, X-inactivation in males and females involves a similar process and we hypothesize that the unusual replication pattern of the allocyclic X in females is represented in the atypical behavior of the X in early prophase of spermatocytes in these bats. The autosomal short arm of the X and the Y2 in stenodermatine species with X-autosome translocations are negatively heteropycnotic when stained with Giemsa and thus correspond to their early replicating banding pattern as seen in female somatic cells. The long arm of the X and the Y, show some heteropycnosis, but not to the degree typical in mammals. The existence of an intermediate replicat ing region of presumed autosomal origin on the X long arm minimizes the area of X chromosome con densation, the overall effect being the disappearance of a typical mammalian sex vesicle.

Relative to data collected on phyllostomid bats, Hayman and Sharp's hypothesis of sex vesicle func tion can be debated. If the primary function of X-inac tivation and sex vesicle formation is associated with the unique pairing behavior of the X and Y, one would expect to see a change in X chromosome con densation between the X in XY,Y2 stenodermatine speeies, where an association between the original X and Y is maintained, and the X in neo-XY speeies, where association between the original X and Y has been replaced by the autosomal translocations. Data presented here support Hayman and Sharp's notion that autosomal pairing replaces pairing of the original X and Y. However, in stenodermatine bats this occurs without a noticeable change in condensation of the X chromosome. Indeed, in some species sex vesicle formation lakes place in the absence of XY pair formation (Pathak et al., 1980) . Additionally, in G. gerbillus. a speeies with multiple sex chromosome autosome translocations, pairing of the original X and Y has been completely replaced by pairing of the translocated autosomes (Wahrman ct al.. 1983) . How ever, sex vesicle formation involving the original X and Y persists.

In general, reproductive patterns of phyllostomid bats indicate seasonal polyestry and production of one or two young per year (Wilson. 1979) . This strategy is one which certainly could not tolerate a meiotic load as has been suggested for the microtine rodent Ellobius lutescens, a species with sex chromosome abnor malities and a high reproductive rate (Lyapunova, 1975) . For these reasons, the disruption of sex vesicle formation presumably does not result in male sterility in phyllostomid bats. This is in contrast to numerous cases in which sterility is associated with disruption of sex vesicle formation in pachynema (Dutrillaux et al., 1972; Laurent and Dutrillaux, 1976; Forejt and Gregorova. 1977; deBoer and Branjc, 1979; Forejt, 1979; Gonzales et al., 1981; Faed ct al., 1982; Laurent et al., 1982) . Disruption of the integrity of the sex vesicle and concomitant sterility in males has been hypothesized to result from a disruption of X-inactivation in spermatogenesis (Lifschytz and Lindsley, 1972) . Given this hypothesis, one must conclude that in viable species, which are characterized by sex chro mosome autosome translocations, both the autoso mal component and, more importantly, the X chro mosomal component of the composite X function autonomously. Data from this study suggest that a strict correlation between or among 1) absence of a sex vesicle, 2) disruption of X-inactivation. and 3) male sterility, cannot be inferred. Ohno (1970) proposed that one function of sex vesicle formation is to minimize pairing or synapsis of the dissimilar X and Y chromosomes. Ashley (1983) suggested that early desynapsis of the X and Y in comparison to autosomal synapsis may have evolved to decrease the chance for exchange between nonhomologous regions of the X and Y. She also reported disruption of the normal program of XY synapsis desynapsis due to X-autosome translocations. Spermatogenic arrest in male mice with sex chromosome autosome translocations has also been attributed to disruption of the normal pairing program of the sex chromosomes (Forejt and Gregorova, 1977) . Indeed, several authors have cited the importance of normal XY pair formation for successful spermatogenesis to occur (Beechey, 1973; Miklos, 1974; Chandley et al., 1976; Chandley. 1979) . In stenodermatine species with X-autosome translocations the autosomal short arm of the X does not effect pairing or association between the presumed original X and Y. In species with both X-and Y-autosome translocations, the autosomal short arm of the X and the autosomal arm of the Y behave autonomously from the remainder of the X and Y. They also appear to disrupt or replace pair ing or association between the original X and Y in late prophase I, but without causing spermatogenic arrest.

In conclusion, data from this study present a chal lenge to the existing hypotheses of sex vesicle forma tion and function. The unique behavior of the XY pair in male gametogencsis in mammals is, perhaps, best studied by a combination of mitotic and meiotic analyses. Clearly, such an approach has provided a greater understanding of sex chromosome activity in spermatogenesis in phyllostomid bats. Future studies of this kind will hopefully further clarify the unique behavior of the sex chromosomes in male gametogenesis in mammals.

FIGREF0.text: the University of Michigan Library 35.7.39.109 -10/7/2021 3:20:13 PMFig. 1. Giemsa-staincd pachytene cells of male stenoderniatine species with X-autosome translocations including (a) Artibeus iiiopinatus (AK7158) and (b) A. jamaicensis (AK8234). The XY,Y, trivalents arc identified. Horizontal bars = 10 pm.

FIGREF1.text: Silver-stained pachy tene cell of a male Artibeus cinereus (AK8I82) showing the typical open ring and tail con figuration of the XY,Y2 trivalent (a). The inset (b) shows the neo-XY bivalent of a male Chiroderma viliosum (AK.8I8I) with the closed ring and tail configuration. Arrows indicate presumable points of associa tion between the "original" X and Y. a Kig. 3. Giemsa-staincd diplotcne (a) and diakincsis (b) cells of a male Artibeus jamaicensis (AK8233). The X Y ,Y 2 tiivalents are identified. Single arrowheads indicate association between the long arm telomere of the X and the Y ,. Double arrowheads indicate chiasma formation between the X short arm and the Y2. Horizontal bars = 10 pm.

FIGREF2.text: Gicmsa-stained neo-XY bivalents from pachytene cells (a-d) and metaphase I cells (t--g) of stcnodcrmatinc species including (a) Arlibeus phaeotis (AK.8243), (b) Vampyrops helleri (AK8184), (c) Sturnira ludovici (AK8178),(d) Chiroderma villosum (AK8225).

FIGREF3.text: Gicmsa-stained pachytene cells of phyllostominc species including (a) Micronycteris brachyotis (AK7087) and (b) Tonatia bidens (AK8207). The XY bivalents are identified. Note in (a) the formation of a sex vesicle and protrusion of autosomal-like chromatin. In (b) the sex vesicle is absent. Horizontal bars = 10 pm.
